Content-Type: text/plain;

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I will suggest a procedure for testing during development:
1) You have already designed a unit and you are clear about the
resposibilities of an object. Let us say the class name is ABC
2) You first write a class called TestABC.java in JUnit framework.
3) Let us assume you have a method called getTokens() in class ABC that is
supposed to give you tokens based on some separators in a string.
4) Before you write this getTokens() method , you should write a method
called testGetTokens() in TestABC class. Here you call this method with the
test cases you have defined (e.g. valid, invalid, boundary values etc) and
check the output with "Assert" method (please see examples that come with
the documentation on JUnit).
5) Now you write the code in ABC.java and implement getTokens() method.
After implementing, compile both the classes and run your test code...
6) Keep on modifying your code unless the test passes.

Done...

You might like to look at some examples as given in JUnit documentation or
the link which 'selena ' has mentioned.

Regards,

Sachin
  -----Original Message-----
  From: Manpreet [mailto:manpreet@...]
  Sent: Wednesday, November 08, 2000 4:02 PM
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: RE: [junit] How to write testcases?


      Hi Sachin,

  Thanx for your mail. The code which i am working on, some of it has
already been written and we are adding new packages to it also. As i wrote
earlier, i have never used Junit. What i want to know is, now suppose i add
a new class to an existing structure(say Abc.java), now what do you suggest,
that should i write another class (TestAbc.java which will be same as the
class(Abc.java) but with certain assumptions where i try to write negative
tests so that my (abc.class) fails to pass the test.

  And finally this TestAbc.java would be put in the package where testcases
are kept, and i will add this suite(TestAbc.java) to the main suite created
by someone else.
  Am i clear ? if not please let me know, as i said i am new to writing
testcases, i need to know, how to start from the scratch.

  Thanx and Regards,
  Manpreet
    -----Original Message-----
    From: sachin gupta [mailto:sachin@...]
    Sent: Monday, March 19, 2001 1:02 PM
    To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    Subject: RE: [junit] How to write testcases?


    Hello Manpreet,

    Your question is not clear to me...could you elaborate more  ? What do u
    mean by different structure ? Has the code already been written or you
have
    to write it etc...

    Regards,

    Sachin

    -----Original Message-----
    From: Manpreet [mailto:manpreet@...]
    Sent: Wednesday, November 08, 2000 2:51 PM
    To: junit@yahoogroups.com
    Subject: [junit] How to write testcases?


    Hi all,

    At the begining, i would say pardon my ignorance.

    I am new to testing, i have written a few testcases(by looking at
exsiting
    testcases) using JUnit, but i am still not confident, how and when to
write
    testcases. When should i make a different testcase and things like that.

    I subscribed to yahoo groups, and found all you intellectuals exchanging
    ideas on Junit which are certainly enlightening.

    My basic question is, Does writing testcases invlove making a different
    structure all together, i mean writing classes and then testing them
    independently from the code which is a part of my application.

    Please if you could write something about how should i proceed to write
    testcases, i would be obliged. Your replies will be highly appreciated.


    Thanx and Regards,
    Manpreet
